item.title: Haskell And Other Stuff
item.description:
This is more of a self reminder than anything else.

During the last 2 weeks, now that the finals are over, I've been (on the technical side of things, outside my job):

  • Toying around with Haskell (my first contact with functional programming)
  • Learning more Python (I use it a lot lately, but I fear getting stuck)
  • Trying Ruhoh! (i.e. this blog)
  • Preparing a new project with a coleague (details yet to be disclosed)

So, por partes:

Haskell

Oh, my. It's fun, it's new (to me), and it forces me to think differently:

  • Recursion, recursion!
  • First class functions
  • Lazy-evaluation

A big thanks to the authors of Real World Haskell. I'm still reading it.

I've read good reviews about Learn You A Haskell, so it might be worth a shot.

Python

I'm still undecided to do the leap towards Python 3. Mainly because I really like Flask as a web framework and hasn't been ported yet (just to name a specific package).

I suppose I'm going to wait until I mature enough some of my half-done packages so I can spice it with Python 3 support.

Anyway, I should grab an up-to-date book and stop complaining.

Ruhoh!

Well, right now I'm pretty happy with it. I'm still customizing it, and it's fun. Nothing more to add right now.

New Project

Just not yet.

item.title: PyCharm And PEP8
item.description:
First, I've got to say that I'm very happy with PyCharm and it's capacity to ease my day-to-day development with Python (I'm still amazed of how working with a Windows box became comfortable).

That being said, PEP8 support could be better. I'm not talking about style-error highlighting. I'm talking about the formatter un-PEP-izing my code.

Then I found that I could easily configure the multi-line method calls wrapping (my main problem) through File > Settings > Style > Python.

So I'm kind of a jerk for complaining.

As per PEP8 checking and warnings, I don't know if there's a more elegant way, but for now it make wonders. Thanks to the people at Ocean Observatories Iniciative and their Confluence wiki.

Replicating the instructions, we have:

  1. Go to File > Settings > External Tools
  2. Click to add a new one
  3. Name, group and description of your choice (only name is required)
  4. I left the checkbox options unchanged
  5. Program: route to pep8 executable (e.g. C:\Python27\Scripts\pep8.exe in my setup)
  6. Parameters: $FilePath$ (can be selected through Insert Macro)
  7. Working Directory: $ProjectFileDir$ (can be selected via Insert Macro)

With this, you can now go to Tools and execute pep8 and see in the IDE console the warnings generated (if any). Is not specially pretty, but it's not ugly.
